    Mdm Claire Chiang See Ngoh (Nominated Member): Sir, I am raising this concern based on a fundamental core value which the Government has repeatedly articulated: the desire to become a gracious society. I think BG Yeo's vision of Singapore becoming the watering hole for Silicon Valley experts to come to Singapore to hone our expertise for the IT commerce sector is a very stimulating and intellectually an uplifting one. I applaud that vision. But if we could also visualise Singapore as a nation where people on wheelchairs who are physically handicapped but mentally brilliant, like Dr William Tan, or not too bright but still able, can mix freely and openly over a jug of beer with other Singaporeans without social stigma, in a barrier-free physical environment, then I say we are a city of graciousness. Because it is a city with intellect, enterprise and humanity prevailing side by side.

    With this vision of a city as a driving value for my cut today, I would like to raise the following issues to the Minister:

    First, what progress has been made on the 1993 Advisory Council's recommendations, and the number of facilities identified for the needs of the disabled?

    Second, do we have a central registry of disabled children to enable us to reach out to kids hidden away by parents? What further resources and support can be committed by the Ministry to help disabled children integrate in the mainstream education?

    Third, could the Minister also reinforce our plea to MOE to persuade neighbourhood school principals to accept disabled children and to create a barrier-free school environment, focusing on physical accessibility to laboratories, canteens and libraries?

    Fourth, another concern is the physical and sexual abuse of disabled children, especially the girls. Can the Minister inform us of past records of such abuses and whether the amendment to the Women's Charter is an enabling legislation to protect them and prevent such abuses?

Column: 1677



    Fifth, PWD, some years ago, assured MCD that it would create a disabled-friendly environment through its walkway upgrading projects, to increase physical accessibility of the disabled. Can the Minister confirm that this is now a HDB policy for all constituencies? At this point, I would like to make a plea to all MPs in this House to take this matter seriously. The disabled wish for a barrier-free physical environment, so that they can manoeuvre their way around in a wheelchair without assistance. Gradient of kerbs, road crossings, ramps are a few suggestions which can be easily designed. These user-friendly features are helpful to all Singaporeans, especially young mothers with infant push-carts. They do not cost a lot. I was heartened to hear from Mr Charles Chong, MP for Pasir Ris, and I applaud his initiative, that his Town Council built a ramp for a handicapped girl to help her get to the car park to go to school every day. These are simple, concrete but significant measures which MPs can do for their constituents to spread the spirit of care and share.

    Sixth, could the Minister reinforce our plea to HDB to establish a policy whereby ground floor units of flats or lift decks can be allocated to families with disabled persons to facilitate their access and mobility?

    Sir, MCD, NCSS and about 56 voluntary welfare organisations have done a lot in the caring of the disabled by offering funding for basic facilities, training and service development. I see the need now to lift our eyes to the community for assistance. I see two areas of focus.

    The first focus is to enhance employment opportunities for disabled persons. We have talked about this during the MOM debate. I am pleased to know that NCSS will be carrying out a survey on employment problems of the disabled, to identify the factors securing and retaining employment for the disabled and the views of employers regarding their employment. This survey will help us develop a strategic plan to improve employment opportunities but, meanwhile, I hope the CDC could channel

Column: 1678

queries and job recommendations through its Helpline. The public sector could take the lead by employing more disabled persons, so as to encourage more employers in the private sector to do the same. But as Minister Dr Lee Boon Yang said a few days ago, the challenge is in changing the mindset of the employers. It looks like we will need a national awareness campaign.

    The second focus is to encourage VWOs to develop informal networks, eg, a disabled children's circle, youth circle or an elderly circle within neighbourhoods to enhance mutual support as well as strengthen inter-agency help networks through sharing of services.

    Sir, I would like to make a call again to all Members of Parliament to support the programmes of MCD, CDC, NCSS and VWOs at each of their constituencies. MCD, given its limited budget, has accomplished many targets in the areas of service provision. We now have to generate community-based initiatives by focusing on enablement and participation approaches to help vulnerable groups reach an optimal level of independent functioning.

    Minister Abdullah Tarmugi has broad shoulders to take on this huge task of community development, but the responsibility of community building requires the collaboration of everyone. I urge the hon. Members of Parliament in this House to support his mission, participate and help to generate an enduring reservoir of resources and helping networks for community bonding. I propose that they visit VWOs, find out the problems faced by their constituents, and serve as a bridge to convey their problems to the respective Government bodies. The experience will only enhance MP-constituent relationship.

    Dr Lee Tsao Yuan (Nominated Member): Sir, in 1995, during the Committee of Supply debate, I proposed a national volunteer services scheme for women.

    I would like to resurface that proposal today. I believe, that as Singapore matures, we need to pay more attention to the issue of social cohesion. If we are not

Column: 1679

careful, stratification of our society along socio-economic lines could occur. Over time, the poor will become better off, while the rich could become even richer so that the gap between the haves and the have-nots could widen, particularly where property and other assets are concerned. In other words, we need to make an effort to develop social bonding at the national level, particularly across socio-economic lines.

    One of the greatest institutions of social bonding that we have in Singapore today is national service. During their two and a half years, men of diverse social backgrounds, eg, the Hokkien speaking, or shall I say Hokkien swearing primary educated man, together with the Cambridge-trained son of the rich tycoon are thrown together. They train together. They eat together. They suffer together. They relax together. And because of these ties, bonds of friendship are forged which transcend socio-economic status. As a result, an understanding and tolerance of others from entirely different social backgrounds is developed, which will stand them in good stead throughout their lives.

    However, this form of social cohesion is absent for women. Schools offer some opportunity but this is limited. As a result, a Chinese girl may grow up never having been to the home of a Malay friend and vice versa. A girl living in a district 11 bungalow may never understand the concerns and mindset of someone who grew up in a rented 3-room HDB flat. There is simply no opportunity to do so.

    I would therefore urge the Government to seriously consider a national cohesion scheme for women. The objectives are clear. First, it is to develop social bonding among women at the national level and, second, in developing that social bonding, it will also foster a greater sense of community, of national identity, of what it means to be Singaporean.

    The best time for such a scheme to occur is after `A' levels where there is a window of about six months before the university term begins. The scheme could involve a range of duties, including social work, health care and administrative

Column: 1680

support services. It should include a physical training programme to develop physical fitness, much like the Outward Bound School.

    In conclusion, I believe that social cohesion and social bonding should not just be for men alone, simply because they have national service and women are excluded. A scheme should be started for women. The beneficial effects of such a scheme are of strategic importance for Singapore. I also believe that in this day and age, this is the time to implement such a scheme. It is a scheme for which the time has come.

    Dr Teo Ho Pin (Sembawang): Sir, my topic is on quality of life.

    If we were to go through the corporate brochures or annual reports of various Ministries and statutory boards, we will find that most of them have impressive mission statements, visions and goals for their respective organisations, many of which strive to develop Singapore into a world-class city, a city that offers diversity and choice, a city with a rich variety of environment, a city of character and grace, and a city with a rich quality of life.

    Although all these mission statements reflect what the respective Ministries or statutory boards would like to achieve in the next century, many fail to reflect what Singaporeans really want in life. While it is easy to define a world-class city, it is difficult to define quality of life. Thus, I would like to urge the Ministry to develop a set of social indicators to measure our quality of life.

    A recent Straits Times report on 2nd June 1997 highlighted that, "Life has become better for Singaporeans in the five years between 1990 and 1995. Singaporeans are richer, better-educated, live in bigger homes and hold better jobs."
12.45 pm

    Another survey which was conducted by Asiaweek in October 1996, ranked Singapore's standard of living second, as compared to 40 other cities in Asia. But, are these measures truly reflective of the quality of life of Singaporeans? I do not

Column: 1681

think so. If you were to conduct house visits to a block of 3- or 4-room HDB flats, you will receive this common feedback from the residents, "Living in Singapore is very good, but life is very tough."

    In some developed countries, the standard of living is improving, but the quality of life does not necessarily improve at the same time. Are people happier, more fulfilled, more creative, more able to develop their potential? Are their relationships at work and leisure as satisfying? Do they find their neighbourhood and environment as pleasant to live in? Is there a supportive network of families, friends, and neighbours to help them in their old age or childcare? All these questions must be properly addressed before we embark on our ambitious plans to develop Singapore into a world-class city. I hope the Ministry could update the House on the quality of life of Singaporeans.

    Sir, I would also like to urge the Ministry to consider developing a Quality of Life index for Singaporeans. Economic indicators are used to track the performance of the economy. We also need Quality of Life indicators to monitor the fulfilment of Singaporeans' needs and aspirations in life.

    Dr Toh See Kiat (Aljunied): Sir, it is commonly acknowledged that there is too much stress in Singapore and, as Dr Teo has eloquently put it, the quality of life is not as it should be. We are too strung-up. We are too serious minded. As the Minister for Information and the Arts said in the debate in this House a few days ago, quoting Mr Sim Wong Hoo, our best and most famous entrepreneur, there is not much of a fun element in Singapore. Even a pressure cooker needs safety valves or else the pot will explode and then whatever you are cooking is useless and wasted. I do believe, Sir, that the pressure cooker that we are in in Singapore needs safety valves. There is anecdotal evidence that more and more children, for example, are going for counselling and the mental health of our nation is at stake. The talents that we are

Column: 1682

nurturing could one day explode and then be wasted. I do not know if there are figures, but if there are, I hope the Minister would reveal them to the House.

    Sir, my purpose today is not just a call to the Minister to do something about this, but also a call to all Singaporeans, my fellow Singaporeans, to remember to work hard and play hard. This is a call to all Singaporeans to keep a healthy mind in a healthy body. Being competitive is fine because we are a small nation that survives on our wits, but being a small nation that is competitive does not mean that we have to spend every single moment making money and forget about our health and forget about our families and having fun with them. Being competitive, without being healthy, is thus foolish.

    My call is also to the Singapore Government to promote sports (not only for the masses, we have been doing that a lot) and I think it is time we move on to a higher level, and that is we should also be promoting sports for professional talents to grow, not just in soccer but in everything else. This may seem like benefiting only a small group of people but as we can see from other nations, every time somebody wins a medal in the Olympics, the whole nation wins and cheers. Every time there is a medal won in the World Cup, not only in soccer, but in all sorts of things, everyone stands up and cheers. So I think it is important now for us to start looking for programmes to groom professional talents and be serious about this because professional talents and champions also serve this purpose of bonding the nation and the community together, and giving us all, you might say, a vicarious national pride in this achievement. We need bigger grants for grassroots organisations, for example, to organise family oriented sports and games and recreational activities and be more proactive in starting some of these programmes.

    My call is also to the Government to promote mental health by building facilities that would give fun, inexpensive fun, for Singaporeans. It is nice to build big resorts or big tourist spots that can also be

Column: 1683

used by locals, but these are expensive and generally if you look at the entrance fees of $15-$16, nobody goes. If you look at the Lianhe Zaobao celebrations, they opened up Tang Dynasty City for a dollar and crowds came. Perhaps we do not have to charge a dollar, maybe $3 or $5, and I think much more response will be there.

    We need to create facilities for Singaporeans to play, recreational facilities that do not cost the earth, perhaps such as adventure campsites. I think we have got adventure campsites that were planned but are now suffering from the regional crisis because these things have to be put on the shelf as they are not deemed to be necessities. Sir, I think that is short-sighted. These are necessities - fishing sites, perhaps even kelong sites. I think PPD and some other agencies discourage Singaporeans from going up to kelongs to just spend a night there, or fish and do things like that. I think we should allow them to do so. We should allow for more outdoor accommodation for fun activities, more parks like Sungei Buloh and Labrador and we should leave Pulau Ubin alone so that it is unburdened with all our improvements. There is value in being able to just run around in the wild, so to speak. Sir, if we leave it untouched, it also helps our Singaporeans to be reminded of the times that we have gone through, that once upon a time in Singapore it was like that. It would give them some lessons in how far we have come and how much we should appreciate the work that we have put in.

    Sir, perhaps this can be modified a little. We might be able to preserve one or two villages in there as pristine as we can. Leave it there, the Malay village or the Chinese village, so that the people would remember how we lived once upon a time. Perhaps for this model village we can put people there. Like in other countries, for example, Plymouth, in Massachusetts, they have got a village there as if it is still living in the 1600s. They have got people moving around, sowing, planting, milling, and so on. Maybe we can do a model village like that just to remind Singaporeans of where we were and how far we have come.

Column: 1684



    Sir, this call is also to the Government - and the Minister for Finance is happily here - for the Minister for Finance to allocate some more funds to the Minister for Community Development so that we can have funds to educate and publicise these things that Singaporeans can do to help them to learn and this is a learned thing to learn the art of relaxation and the proper use of leisure time.

    Dr Ho Tat Kin (Bishan-Toa Payoh): Sir, the Government adopts a many helping hands approach in the provision of social service. This approach harnesses the collaborative efforts of Government agencies and non-government organisations in the provision of social welfare and community support services and programmes for the less fortunate in our society.

    Sir, although a wide range of services has been put in place by various organisations, the general public or even social service agencies may not be aware of the availability of the full range of services. MCD could perhaps identify specific target groups which would be most likely to need such social service. I believe the group that needs this service most are usually low income families staying in the 1-room or 2-room rental units. I understand there are about 100,000 households in this category. MCD, together with CDC volunteers, could target this group for an extensive outreach programme. CDC volunteers could first be trained to understand the entire scope of social services available. The volunteers in their encounters with these families would then be able to explain, and also assist those who need such service, to apply for them or help to refer them to the relevant authorities.

    Sir, may I ask what measures will be taken to provide greater publicity on the different types of social service available so as to reach a wider audience?

    Dr S. Vasoo (Tanjong Pagar): Sir, I feel we should ask ourselves one basic question. Are we giving enough help to the voluntary sector? I am sure Members would be able to assess this. They have been involved in the various voluntary

Column: 1685

sectors and encouraged people to participate in various voluntary activities. Sir, my own assessment is that, yes, we have given some help to a certain extent. Moral support and encouragement, plenty. You and I can give all this to the many organisations. But this is insufficient. Just appeal to the hearts and cajole people is a good thing, but it is insufficient because a lot of efforts go into the raising of funds, to run projects and to translate ideas, interests, concerns, into concrete programmes.

    If you assess the financial grants given to voluntary organisations, I would say that some are given, perhaps a little. Let me tell you what has been provided to the voluntary sector. First, you have the matching grants for various programmes. It is up to 50% for selected programmes. The voluntary organisation has to raise the rest. It is a good thing, but how much can you raise because a lot of organisations are competing out there for funds, including the CDCs today who are also in the scene competing to raise funds from various people. And you and I are being cajoled all the time. It is good if we can help. But I think at some point, many of us could suffer from compassion fatigue. But, nevertheless, we should do something for the community.

    For capital grant, I think there is good mileage because organisations get up to 95%, but these are for a few buildings, and new facilities and other developments. This is an interesting development and I must say that the Ministry has given support in this aspect. For many of the voluntary organisations, their facilities need to be upgraded and I see that some of the facilities are really down to the pits. So what we have to do is to see what can be done in terms of providing grants for them to upgrade their facilities. I assert that more could be done in this area.

    Sir, I know that moral support alone is insufficient. I can understand the Minister's predicament. He has been persuading the Ministry of Finance, year in and year out, to get more funds and since the Minister for Finance is here this afternoon, I am glad he is here, I see that it

Column: 1686

is important that he be persuaded to support community building cause and to note that the funds that he will be releasing is in terms of investment for the social infrastructure. It is the people that we are looking at, ie, community building and community cohesion. We want to prevent social divide in the community. If the community is divided, how could we harness them to be productive people? Sir, almost every sector of the community is important to us. Whether they are the able or disabled, I feel it is important for us to find ways to support them. And I hope that next year the Minister for Finance would be better persuaded to release more funds. I am sure my colleagues would agree with these suggestions and persuasion.
1.00 pm

    Sir, I hope that the Minister would consider this matter seriously. And I hope he is not suffering from compassion fatigue but able to see what he can do to boost the voluntary sector as well as the Ministry of Community Development.

    Sir, increasingly voluntary organisations are also encouraged to provide more and more services. We ask them to develop programmes. We persuade them with all good intentions and purposes. Many of them want to do good. But how can we help them to have a better mileage, in terms of contributing to the community? What more than by providing them adequate funds to enable them to achieve the missions and objectives to do public good. This is an area where we should examine seriously, in terms of what support we can give them.

    Sir, some of these organisations are affected by spending a lot of time in raising funds. I suppose more than 70% of their time is spent in raising funds and 20% in terms of service delivery, thinking about what and how they can plan ahead. So I hope we can relieve them of this fund-raising burden. It is not easy to raise funds today, because many of us are all the time approached by many organisations, persuading us to do what is possible, and many of them are very supportive. I hope that people will

Column: 1687

continue to do so, but there is a threshold to how much we can do. And the heart of the matter is that volunteers and others can do things up to a point. But Government must demonstrate its capacity to do more and should be encouraged to do a little more so that it could inspire more volunteers and people in the community to contribute to this common good. To reduce the problem and burden of fund-raising, it is necessary for the Ministry to persuade the Ministry of Finance to increase grants for the voluntary sector. I would like to persuade the Minister for Finance to see whether the CDC funding formula of $3 to $1 could be applied to the voluntary sector, ie, for every $1 raised, the Government will give $3. If it is matched by that formula, then I think the voluntary sector would be able to do more and the community would be able to benefit in the longer term. We will be able to reduce the social divide in the community and people will participate fully in community building.

    I hope that the funding formula and support for the voluntary sector could be reviewed and the Minister for Finance would be able to think of ways in which he can urge and encourage people to do more.

    Mdm Claire Chiang See Ngoh: Sir, I would like to know from the Minister what measures have been taken to improve the professionalism of the social worker sector. Based on a number of conversations I had with various people following my maiden speech in November last year, I have observed some uncertain sentiments.

    There is a fear that by recognising the professionals through accreditation measures, we may risk losing thousands of needed good-hearted volunteers who may now "disqualify". That is not so. In fact, the feedback is we are losing volunteers because of unclear role expectations, low professionalism, absence of training and self-growth opportunities and weak volunteer development programmes. Moreover, volunteers can still be accredited by experience and performance accordingly. They can also take up course modules in their work

Column: 1688

experience and become progressively professionalised, so to speak. So they will not be excluded.

    On the side of the professionals, for the sake of protecting public interest, they feel strongly the need to differentiate the volunteers and professionals by skills so that the qualified and certified social work professionals will handle therapy related work and the social work volunteers or non-accredited staff can be trained to offer other administrative, management and non-clinical client-related services.

    The confusion of the word "social worker" which has been used very loosely in the community and by the media because it is referred interchangeably to everybody - professionals, non-accredited staff and volunteers in the field. They assume that social workers are primarily volunteers. Sometimes legitimately so because a social work professional can be a volunteer. A volunteer in the social work sector, on the other hand, may not have professional qualifications. And a staff not trained at all in the social work discipline, who is managing a VWO, is also seen as a social worker. Everyone, irrespective of qualifications and skills, as long as she contributes in the social service sector becomes commonly known as a social worker. That is the root of the confusion.

    I would like to highlight to Members of the House that they are different in their areas of focus, the kind of training they bring to the field and the sort of professional outcome and work performance we expect from their participation. We must develop a system of job functions and skills levels. Once clear work roles are established and their contributions are organised in complementary terms, the closer we are towards developing an action model of cooperation for enhancing performance standards in that sector.

    I hope the Minister will continue his effort in pursuing the need to professionalise the social service sector and accord due recognition by accreditation, rank and remuneration of social workers.

Column: 1689



    On another matter, Sir, there were special requests from numerous VWOs whether we could give direct service volunteers some incentives to influence a minimum standard of services. Sixty-one agencies, about 82% in a survey of 75 VWOs last year, conducted by NCSS, expressed problems in sustainment and deployment of volunteers. Organisations which focus on their service delivery standards through training are finding it difficult to retain their volunteers. I was told that an occasional praise, a door gift, lucky draw prizes, a certificate or inspirational talks and stories are no longer adequate to motivate these thousands of people to give up their leisure and take up the burden of fulfilling someone else's need on a regular basis. On top of this, like Dr Vasoo says, these people are asked to look for funds to perpetuate their own sacrifice.

    There are about 12,500 lonely elderly poor in Singapore; the number is going to grow to 17,500 by the year 2030. Unless such people are befriended for psycho-emotional support, kept clean and fed by volunteers or full-time staff, they would become early candidates for nursing homes. It was calculated for me that it costs the community less than $50 per month for each of these elderly to be supported by volunteers. In a nursing home it would cost $1,000 per month.

    We need an average of 2,000 volunteers to assist direct service VWOs to care for the chronic sick, the disabled, the young and the abandoned individuals. The social burden on the state will increase. We need to look deep into community resources by mobilising and deploying the thousands of homemakers and retirees for action. By giving them basic training in care programmes, they form a significant community of reservist volunteers whom we should bestow some degree of prestige and privilege.

    Sir, there are two views about the use of material incentives. One which urges us to accept the reality of the voluntary movement and offer material incentives to attract and retain volunteers. The second

Column: 1690

view sees the use of material incentives as a wrong spirit to promote in voluntarism. Moreover, by having the Government stepping in to do this, a whole lot of requests from other quarters will follow. What limits and on whom does the Government impose? And how much is enough as benefits to volunteers, anyway? So although I support Dr Vasoo's call for more support for the volunteers, I think this is a complex issue that we need to handle cautiously.

    A middle view sees the voluntary movement being organised and incentivised at the NGO level, but there is then an overall need to critically examine if the resources and management capabilities of NGOs can effect such an outcome. We need advocates and leaders in the social service sector who are not care-givers, therapists or social work professionals, but are good managers with a helicopter view for developing community initiated programmes.

    Sir, some strategic planning and visioning is urgently needed to promote voluntarism as a philosophy and a movement. NCSS is working hard at this, but the Government must step in to support with resources and public education programmes. If not, the State will only be saddled with increasing social burden costs and a desperate lot of Singaporeans with no one taking care of them.

    We seek the Minister's direction and leadership on this matter.

    Mr S. Iswaran (West Coast): Sir, today in Singapore, the planning and delivery of community and social services occurs at three levels.

    The second is at the district level. With the advent of Community Development Councils last year, we now have the equivalent of local governments to cater to the needs of residents at the CDC district level.

    Sir, clearly, there is a need for coordination and cooperation across these three tiers. And it already occurs to some extent. In this way, each party is able to add value according to their strengths.

    The Minister for Community Development (Mr Abdullah Tarmugi): Sir, I thought I should stop the debate here for a while to reply to some of the questions. I am not too sure whether I can finish answering everyone by the time the "guillotine" for my Ministry comes into effect.

We have questions on juvenile delinquency, child abuse, and child care centres. These three gentlemen raised some questions and concerns on the issue of juvenile delinquency.
1.15 pm

    Sir, the issue of juvenile delinquency is a very complex one. There is till now no single, quick fix solution to the problem of juvenile delinquency in any community. And in any community, no matter at which stage of development it is in, there is the problem of juvenile delinquency. The best approach is a multi-disciplinary and multi-pronged one which involves the community, the Government, the VWOs and, most importantly, the parents. So we involve the schools, social service agencies, the Police, the community, teachers, preachers, friends and, most importantly, as I said, the parents. At the local level, we already have a network involving the different agencies. At the national level, I am not too sure whether Members are aware that there is an Inter-Ministry Committee on Juvenile Delinquency chaired by the Minister of State for Home Affairs. This Committee looks into all problems of juvenile delinquency which are brought up by the various Ministries and coordinates the efforts of the various Ministries.

    There are two approaches which the Government takes on juvenile delinquency. One, is the preventive and development programmes approach, and, two, the reinforcement and rehabilitative programmes approach. In terms of preventive programmes, we have an

Column: 1693

intensive public education programme to make people aware of the dangers of juvenile delinquency and also how to prevent juvenile delinquency from happening. We have linking of schools with MCD and social service agencies. We have in schools a checklist for teachers and also for VWOs where they can identify children or students who are at risk and would need help so that schools can refer them to FSCs or professional social workers to be counselled. They can be helped. Then of course there is the Before-and-After-School programme.

    In terms of enforcement and rehabilitation programmes, we have the Guidance Programme for Police Caution Cases, the National Youth Council's Streetwise programme and networking between MCD and social service agencies to provide counselling, support and supervision for juvenile delinquents.

    Dr Yaacob asked how do we keep our children and teenagers occupied so as to prevent them from becoming juvenile delinquents. As you know, there are many programmes organised by the People's Association Youth Movement, the National Youth Council, and the social service agencies to keep the children occupied. Even the BASCs will keep them occupied to ensure that they keep themselves away from bad peer influence. And we will be looking into more ways to see how children could be distracted from bad peer influence into activities which are wholesome and useful for them when they grow up.

    There is one interesting point which Dr Vasoo and Mr Rai brought up, and that is, empowering schools to send children beyond parental control (BPC) cases to the Homes. I am reluctant to support this and I would not want to advocate this proposal. Let me explain. If we do this, we will run across problems with differing standards of assessment by teachers or principals. Some principals may be more than happy to send their students direct to the Homes. But some other principals or teachers may have more stringent standards; in other words, they will not want to send them to

Column: 1694

the Homes. We may have very differing standards and we may also encourage schools to be less stringent in trying to help their students because it is an easy avenue for them to get rid of problem students.

    The most important thing is that it is not fair for us to place this very heavy responsibility on the schools. Whether we like it or not, they may suffer the stigma of being sent to the Homes. The thing to do is to empower the parents instead, not the schools. We must put the whole responsibility of looking after the children on the parents. Therefore, we need to reinforce parental responsibility. We have to ensure that parents get the help and the knowledge parenting knowledge to look after their children and to bring up their children properly.

    There are avenues, Sir, in the community which parents can turn to. They can go to the Family Service Centres for help. They can come to my Ministry for help, advice or counselling. And if a child is really recalcitrant, the parents can lodge a complaint. The parents must lodge a complaint to the Juvenile Court and the child may be placed under statutory supervision or admitted to an approved Home. It is a serious matter before a child can be sent to a Home. So I do not think we want to empower the schools to send children direct to the Homes. I think it is unfair to them. Sending of children to the Homes should be a last resort, something which we would not do and something which we only do after trying other ways to solve the child's problems.

    Mr Shriniwas Rai and Dr Yaacob also asked about the Boys' Home and measures to improve the Boys' Home. Members must have heard about the recent riot which happened in the Boys' Home. It is something which we did not want to happen, but it happened. The Singapore Boys' Home, as has been mentioned yesterday, is over 100 years. We face problems of staff. There is overcrowding. But, more importantly, the profile of the boys that are admitted into the Homes has changed over the years. Previously, the number of boys with history of violence or involvement in

Column: 1695

violent crimes was about 20% but now it is about half, or 50%. In other words, the kinds of children and teenagers that are being sent to the Homes are different. About 90% of these boys have previous secret society or gang connections.

    Since the attempted break-out, MCD had further upgraded the security of the Home because security was the immediate concern. We had brought in the Prisons Department. We had sought the advice of the Police on how to increase the security of the Home. We even had to employ CISCO officers as guards because, previously, we had only commercial guards.

    We had some of our internal procedures reviewed and tightened our management and control of the boys in the Home. There will be a new Home for the boys to replace the Boys' Home. It will be ready by the end of the year. And in the new Home, we hope that things will be better. The environment will be better, there will be more facilities, more space, and security will be better. We would also improve the staff/resident ratio. So be assured that we have looked at the problem very carefully. We will continue to monitor the boys there and we will see to it that the conditions in the new Home will be so much better than the old one.

    Amendments to the Children and Young Persons (CYP) Act are being thought of by my Ministry. We will be amending the Act to include provisions for enhancement in the treatment of young offenders and those who are beyond parental control. There will be new sentencing options which will be available and will provide the courts with a wider choice in selecting an appropriate treatment for the kinds of cases that come up to them. In the amendment too, we will see to it that not only parents but also family members are more involved in the rehabilitation of children.

    I would like to thank Mr Rai - I am afraid he is not here - who has offered to help review the CYP. The CYP has in fact gone through a lot of discussions between my Ministry and the courts, the Police, the AG's Chambers and even the GPC for

Column: 1696

Community Development. I intend to table the amendments in this House later this year. However, I would be pleased to receive views and suggestions from the NMP in the meantime.

    Mr Rai also suggested that instead of sending children to court, he would rather that a tribunal, similar to the Tribunal for the Maintenance of Parents, be set up to deal with juvenile delinquency. This is to divert the juveniles from the juvenile delinquency system and also not to criminalise the boys. We support the use of diversionary measures wherever possible and we too believe that the juvenile court should be the last resort where boys should be sent to for treatment and rehabilitation. But we do not think that a tribunal is necessary because a tribunal, as proposed, will also include a judge and a judge will preside and thereby it would be similar to a court or at least a quasi-court.

    The NMP also suggested that there should be social workers to sit with the judges in dealing with cases. This is happening, Sir. In the juvenile court setup, we have a court system but we also have a magistrate who sits with at least two members of the panel of advisors who are laymen (not lawyers), who may be teachers and social workers to advise or hear the case together with the judge. They serve to advise the magistrate on the possible treatment of cases and to discuss the case with the magistrate.

    Prof. Low also asked about the Boys' Home. I think I have answered some of his concerns. He suggested that there should be better programmes in the Home. I am glad to say that in the new premises, there will be a classification centre where all new committals will begin their rehabilitation programme. Each boy will be assessed by a team of officers and an individual treatment plan will be designed for each inmate and a contract worked out. In other words, there will be a more sensitive classification system, so that each inmate or each committal boy will be better looked after in that sense.
1.30 pm

    As regards staff/resident ratio, I agree with Members that the ratio of 1:40 for the

Column: 1697

existing homes is simply unacceptable. We will look into this and we will improve the staff/resident ratio in the new complex.

    On child care centres, Assoc. Prof. Low Seow Chay asked whether there ought to be stricter control over the usage of child care centre premises. He mentioned that some of the child care centres, instead of administering the programmes as determined by my Ministry, come out with a lot of enrichment programmes. They even refuse to take in extra students because they feel that the students will not be "enriched" enough if they take in more students. I would like to inform the Member that there are child care regulations which stipulate that child care premises cannot be used for any purpose, other than the ordinary conduct and business of a child care centre. Our officers visit these centres frequently and, in fact, there is an annual report. In other words, we have an annual assessment of each centre and we use a list of criteria to evaluate the centres. The Ministry, however, does allow child care centres to conduct one approved enrichment programme, in addition to the normal programme for children enrolled in the centre.

    Assoc. Prof. Low also mentioned the shortage of child care places. This problem apparently arises every year, that there are not enough places and there are long waiting lists. But the truth of the matter, as I have answered at a previous sitting, is that there are enough places and, indeed, some centres have vacancies. The problem is that parents want to choose more popular centres, and they want to choose preferably centres below their blocks. Therefore, there are some centres which are over subscribed and there are other centres which are empty or which have vacancies, simply because parents tend to choose centres which are more convenient to them or which they prefer. So if we look at the child care centre situation at the macro level, there are enough places. The supply is enough for the demand. But if we look

Column: 1698

at each child care centre, there seems to be some mismatch between what the parents want and what the centres can provide.

    Right now, there are 464 child care centres providing places for 38,000 children. Another 40 new child care centres for an additional 3,000 children will be provided this year. We will continue to provide sites. We will continue to monitor demand and supply and, if need be, we will continue to build more child care centres.

    Prof. Chin Tet Yung feels that MCD should take a more positive role in planning and coordinating the provision of facilities in child care centres. Mr Zulkifli calls for a national child care centre system where Government will be involved in the setting up and running of child care centres. As of now, actually Government is very deeply involved, as I mentioned earlier, in the development of child care centres. It has regulations for these centres. It sends officers to check and monitor the progress of these centres.

    MCD actually adopts a three-pronged approach in developing child care centres. First, to ensure that there is availability and accessibility of child care centres; second, to ensure that child care centres are affordable; and, third, we want to ensure the quality of the child care centres.

    We project the demand of child care centres, review such projections annually, and we take into consideration HDB's housing development plans in new estates. So there is already close coordination between my Ministry, HDB, URA and the Land Office in terms of location of child care centres and availability of sites for child care centres in the estates. HDB will indeed be incorporating child care centres and other social facilities in its building plans for new estates, and, as far as possible, to have such facilities built in tandem with the development of the estates in the future. Therefore, once we have the estates, we will have the child care centres and other social facilities built up at the same time.

Column: 1699



    In terms of quality, MCD ensures that there are enough training programmes for child care centre teachers and supervisors, training programmes by accredited agencies. We set the curriculum for the training to ensure standards. MCD also gives training awards to those who are interested in pursuing a full-time career in child care centres. The award comprises a grant for fees and allowance during the duration of the course. And on completion of the course, the candidate is allowed to work in any child care centre. In other words, there is no bond. The person is not bound to work in any centre. He is free to work in any non-profit organisation's centre or in a private child care centre if he or she wants.

    Prof. Chin asked for tax rebate for child care courses. I am afraid there are no such rebates, but SDF, I am told, provides 80% funding for course fees, whether it is basic course, intermediate course or advanced course. In addition, SDF also funds 50% of the course fees for first aid and other enrichment courses. I think there is really no need for tax rebates for people to go to child care courses.

    Coming to the supply of child care centres in Woodlands, Prof. Chin commented that MCD was slow or rather sluggish in the development of child care centres in his constituency. The Member must be aware that there are currently 12 child care centres providing 920 child care places in the Woodlands estate. The total enrolment in these 12 centres is about 90% right now, and there are, in fact, still 50-odd vacancies in these centres.

    As regards the long waiting list, I have given the reasons just now. They are mainly for the more popular centres in the ward. Assoc. Prof. Chin may not be aware that for some years, Woodlands had only two centres and the utilisation of these two centres was actually poor. Consequently, private and non-profit organisations were actually reluctant to set up child care centres in the estate for some time. Despite this, my Ministry pushed for the development of more centres in the estate and as the estate expanded. And within two years, between 1996 and 1997, 10 new centres became operational, and

Column: 1700

10 more with a total of 780 places are being planned for the estate. Out of this number, I am told that six are already under construction and will be ready by the end of this financial year. If demand still exceeds supply despite all this building, my Ministry will consider building more child care centres in Woodlands.

    Dr Toh See Kiat asked for more child care centres in the workplace. I cannot agree with him more on this. It is very important and I think it is very convenient for parents to have child care places in their workplace. Indeed, we have been working toward this. We have been trying to do this for quite sometime now. The benefits of child care centres in the workplace are immense. I think nobody can argue against it. It is mutually beneficial for the employer as well as for the employees. And it is also good for the bottom line of the companies.

    The Government has been setting an example in this. It has taken the lead in providing child care centres in workplaces. There are about 30 workplace centres in various Government departments. Actually, there are a lot of incentives for companies to set up child care centres at their premises. There are financial subsidies, for example, which we give to non-profit organisations, and which we also extend to firms. In addition, the firms are allowed to claim expenses incurred in capital expenditure and subsidies given to employees for child care as tax deductive expenditure. They may also claim industrial building allowance on capital expenditure for the renovation and conversion of their premises. In fact, there are already enough incentives for firms to set up child care centres in their buildings, and we will continue to find and to encourage more companies to build such centres in their workplace.

    Madam Claire Chiang spoke very extensively on the disabled, and she made a rallying call. I am thankful for that. I think MPs at the local level can help as advisers to their grassroots organisations. They can network with other VWOs. They can network with CDCs to ensure that there

Column: 1701

are enough help or social agencies or institutions to help the disabled in their constituencies.

    It has always been my Ministry's philosophy that the disabled can live meaningful lives and can be integrated in the community. In fact, they ought to be. It is better for them to be integrated into the community, rather than being put aside in institutions or being hidden at home.

    She mentioned three areas of focus - training, employment and informal support networks. In terms of training, we actually have many agencies serving disabled people, which also run training programmes, eg, Rainbow Centre, Down Syndrome Association, Singapore Association for the Visually Handicapped, Canossian School for the Hearing Impaired. They have training programmes for disabled people.
1.45 pm

    I agree with the NMP that employment plays a very important role in the integration of disabled people into the community. My Ministry, in fact, together with NCSS set up Bizlink Centre in 1988. So the Centre is 10 years old now. It is now known as Bizlink Centre Singapore Limited. It is a central body to coordinate employment assistance for disabled persons in Singapore. It works together with the Ministry of Education and also the Ministry of Labour and provides vocational assessment and assistance and also job placements for the disabled.

    Indeed the Centre's data bank has about 2,000 potential employers which we can draw on to provide employment to the disabled. We feel that there is scope for Bizlink to work together with CDCs to reach out to the community for job placement/assessment of the disabled. We will see that this happens and we will encourage such coordination between Bizlink and the CDCs and the community.

    The Government also funds vocational training programmes leading to Certificates of Vocational Training for Basic Computer Applications, Office Practice

Column: 1702

and Service Skills for the handicapped to ensure that they have the skills for employment.

    To encourage employment of disabled persons, the Government also provides financial incentives to employers, like tax rebates for modifications which they make in the workplace to enable the disabled to work, and for reimbursements of the first 1 1/2 months of the disabled employee's salaries, as well as transport and food allowance, for the disabled worker, where needed. In other words, there are incentives for employers to employ the disabled and we would certainly encourage employers to look into the disabled as a source of manpower.

    The public sector actually is the largest single employer of the disabled people. As at end of last year, we have about 224 disabled persons employed in the public sector and we will increase that number when we find suitable disabled to work in the civil service. But the greatest obstacle to the disabled, as I mentioned this afternoon, is the prejudice against the disabled in the community, that existed in the community itself and this is something I think we have to tackle through public education, through the public knowing more about what the disabled can and cannot do.

    She also asked about the recommendations of the Advisory Council for the Disabled. It is quite a long list, Sir. I could provide the NMP with the list if she needs it. It is quite a long one and most of them have been implemented.

    With regard to schools, where possible, disabled children are integrated in normal schools. There are no barriers, physically, to the handicapped and schools have been cooperative. Where there are handicapped in the school they make sure that mobility and access for the disabled are made as easy as possible, where necessary and appropriate. But we feel that it is not always advantageous for the disabled children to be sent to normal school because some of them are mentally disabled. Therefore it may be better for them to attend special schools

Column: 1703

instead of going to normal schools, where they can be better looked after, where their needs and learning can be tailored more to their level of understanding.

    On barrier-free environment, she did mention that the BCD has got a Code on Barrier-free Accessibility in Buildings. It was I think revised in 1995. The code requires new buildings to have barrier-free features such as toilets for the handicapped, ramps with gentle slopes and kerb ramps which slope upwards from the road to the building. In other words, there is a gentle slope from the road to the building walkways instead of a sharp angle.

    New buildings have to conform to the requirements of this code and old buildings would have to comply with these revised requirements when they undergo major renovations. HDB, I am told, has also incorporated accessibility features in the new HDB buildings as well as existing buildings which are being upgraded in the Main Upgrading Programmes.

    On the provision of ground floor units for families of the disabled, HDB does allocate ground floor flats where they are available and possible for families of the disabled. In the rental flats, they are also given ground floor flats and also flats at lift landings and when they transfer their flats they are also given priority for ground floor units.

    With regard to sexual abuse of disabled individuals, this is something which we all abhor. It is right that we feel very strongly against this, and I agree. I share the NMP's concern about physical and sexual abuse of disabled individuals, particularly the young ones and the girls.

    The provisions in both the Children and Young Persons Act, as well as the Women's Charter, protect all victims from abuse, including the disabled. In fact, the amendments to the Women's Charter provide an added avenue through which help can be obtained, for example, the Charter now allows persons to apply for a protection order on behalf of an abused victim. In other words, for the disabled

Column: 1704

person who could not make any report, a protection order can be applied for on behalf of that person by other persons.

    I think the NMP also asked about the central registry for disabled. She may want to know that there was a Registry of Disabled People or CRDP which was established by the then Ministry of Social Affairs in 1969. But there were some inherent difficulties in maintaining the Registry because of people being reluctant to report, infrequent reporting and very unreliable reporting. Therefore, in 1988, the Advisory Council on the Disabled recommended for the CRDP to be discontinued. But currently, I am told that welfare organisations working with the disabled themselves maintain their own registry of the disabled who are under their charge and they update these registries regularly.     Dr Lee Tsao Yuan talks about a national cohesion scheme for women. This is quite a different subject from what the other speakers have been talking about. But I agree with the sentiments about the need for cohesion. There are avenues for males but apparently there is none for females. There is something about being in the trenches together, eating together, wallowing in the mud together for National Servicemen. They do set up this bond between the rich and poor, between the Hokkien, the Cantonese and the Malay and the Indian or whatever race. So I agree with the sentiments. The question is whether NS should be extended to women. This question is one which Government is still looking into. It has not dismissed the idea. But there are several issues which we need to look into very carefully. For example, the reasons for having NS for women in the first place. Well, she has given one reason, to encourage cohesion and bonding among women. Other issues are whether we should enlist all women or some of the women, and at what level. Who should be enlisted? Which Ministry should be in charge? What would the enlistees do?

Column: 1705

These are issues which have to be carefully looked into and, as the Member mentioned, the scheme ought to be very carefully formulated.

    I am glad to say that we shall look into her suggestions, to see whether a modified form of National Service can be implemented for some women in Singapore. But notwithstanding that, NS is not the only way to bring about social bonding and social cohesion among women. They could engage in social service, they could go down to the constituencies and join the CDCs; they can join as Civil Defence volunteers. They can help in the self-help groups. Indeed there are many opportunities for women to get together and help out others. I think through such involvement in the community, our girls would be able to interact with Singaporeans from all walks of life and from all income groups. Besides deriving personal satisfaction, they somehow very quickly learn to understand the plight and circumstances of the families and individuals whom they work with and whom they help. They are able to empathise with those who come from completely different socio-economic backgrounds, but they share, nevertheless, a common identity of being Singaporeans.

    Dr Teo Ho Pin talked about quality of life. The definition of quality of life can be very nebulous. Different people have different definitions of what a good quality of life is. I grew up in an urban slum, and I used to have a neighbour who was a hawker, who had eight children. To all intents and purposes, he considered his life as of good quality. He said, "I have got no problems. I don't owe any mortgages. I don't have money in the bank but I have enough to eat." To him, quality of life is good. And yet I know of someone who earns $25,000 a month, who keeps on complaining he has not got enough and that his quality of life is somehow very rotten. So the definition of quality of life indeed can vary between one individual and another. But even then I agree that we should not neglect the development of

Column: 1706

social and community infrastructure and we should not just measure quality of life by material standards alone.

    When the PM presented his ideas on Singapore 21 last year, he said that Singapore needs to go beyond economic and material needs and reorient society to meet the intellectual and emotional, spiritual, cultural and social needs of our people. In this regard, my Ministry will continue to develop policies, programmes and infrastructure for individuals to lead a more meaningful and balanced life through promoting community bonding and social cohesion and inculcating family values, promoting voluntarism and caring for the young, the aged and the needy.

    On the issue of quality of life indicators, again this is something which we have to think about. We have to work at definitions. We have to work at measurements and at the indices. We have now on-going a survey on the state of families in Singapore. It is being carried out by my Ministry. We hope it will produce some important social indicators for Singapore. If Members have any proposals on what kind of indicators ought to be included in this index, my Ministry would be most happy to receive it.
2.00 pm

We agree that Singaporeans work hard but we also agree that they must learn to make meaningful use of their leisure. They must have some balance in life. In this respect, the Singapore Sports Council, which is under the Ministry, has done quite a lot, in terms of promoting sports at the community level Sports for Life and also the SPEX 2000 programme.

    With regard to the Sports for Life programme, since its launch in September 1996 from Sports for All programme, we had made a survey last year on sport participation. It was revealed that the percentage of regular sport participation had increased from 24% in 1992 to 34% in 1997, within five years, so a 10% increase within five years. But what is significant is that 72% of the participants spend more

Column: 1707

than 45 minutes in each session. This is very significant because it shows not only the regularity of participation in sports but also the length of each session. And for 72% to spend more than 45 minutes is indeed significant.

    The Singapore Sports Council has launched a public education programme to promote the message that sports is not only fun but it is also beneficial to one's fitness and to oneself. The SSC has now embarked on a second phase of this national public education campaign. The mass media will organise road shows, exhibitions, to bring home the message that sports is fun, it is easy to take up and it is healthy. The campaign will impress on Singaporeans that we do not have to be fit to take up sports but rather sports will develop fitness.

    In the classrooms, teachers wield considerable influence on the students in the way they teach and behave. There is definitely a link between teacher-effectiveness and school performance. The planned changes in the National Education programme, information technology, creativity and thinking skills and curriculum review, will not be successful if we do not have the support and commitment of the teachers. The teachers must be persuaded to own the new approaches in teaching methodology, instructional materials and assessment modes. We have to find new and better ways to involve teachers in empowering them to enhance their work performance and bring about the desired outcomes in our students. Perhaps the Minister can give us an update on the progress made in the implementation of the key initiatives of the Education Ministry.

I hope the Ministry will consider carefully whether any wage restraint exercise in the civil service should be extended to those in the Education Service. I believe that there is still some catching up to do in the remuneration package of the teachers. Now is a good time for our teachers to be recognised and rewarded with competitive salaries, promotion and career development opportunities. This will enhance the status of teachers in our society.

Column: 1726

uplift the morale of the teachers. Teacher-principal relation is important. The transfers and postings of principals to new schools should be better planned and communicated to teachers, students and parents. Teachers are affected by the leadership and competencies of principals in making firm and fair decisions. Teachers are also affected when they perceive inequitable distribution of workload assigned by the principal. Teachers also lament that they have to take on administrative and clerical work at the expense of their teaching roles. We should build and develop more trusting relationship and team spirit among principals and teachers in our school. "If you are my teacher for a day, I will respect you like my father for my whole life time". This saying reflects how much respect students in the old days had for their teachers. Column: 1728

look after National Education, thinking and creativity, computer teaching, etc. As a result, they are highly stressed in the classroom and they really crave that they can have "three heads and six arms". That shows how much pressure is put on the teachers.

    Generally, the teachers have to upgrade themselves to catch up with the latest technology. On the other hand, the pace of the schools is on the move all the time and they may well suffer the "fatigue syndrome". for a certain teacher whom they were very fond of but had lost contact with. They found the teacher and had a memorable reunion. I was very touched by this report. I do not know whether the Minister has read this report in the newspaper. If he has not, I can supply him with the relevant cuttings.

our students have done well, often times performing better in international examinations and surveys than their counterparts from larger and more developed countries. among our teachers, students and parents and better performance and discipline from our students.

    Sir, I will now move on to the needs to reduce the course content to make

Column: 1733

learning easier and more efficient for our students. Our children work very hard in schools. The result of their effort is good grades and success. In the future where information and knowledge decide the outcomes of competition, our students must also acquire the ability to think more and to be more creative and innovative. Our students must therefore continue to score in their examinations while becoming more creative and innovative in their thinking process. At the same time, one should not be achieved at the expense of the other. This is no easy task. If we do not do it right, our students will become more stressed out. One way is to help our students to study more efficiently. With interconnected computers, there is less need to memorise volumes of information which has grown rapidly over the years, partly also a consequence of IT. and to imbue our teachers with the resources and skills to teach with the computer.

While I do not have any empirical evidence of the situation in other communities, I believe there is some relevance here.

It has taken this country and community so much and for so long to give parents the hope, promise and optimism and the feeling that in Singapore, despite differences in race, language, religion and income group, their children have equal opportunities to progress and achieve the desired academic success. But there is a danger that parents may become frustrated and disappointed if they continue to feel helpless to assist and guide their children.

Many of these parents have discovered that the methods and concepts taught in school today are alien to many of them. Quite naturally, some of these parents see tuition as the only solution to these problems. This brings about a host of other problems, namely, stress, excessive workload, complaints of high tuition fees. I

Column: 1736

think we should not allow parents to feel that the academic achievement is dependent upon the amount of tuition that students get. Parental guidance and help are more significant factors. Perhaps in this situation, we can think of grants or loans or something which we can give to help them send their children to university or for further studies. And if this is needed, perhaps we can even look at relaxing our rules on the use of CPF savings.

    The other thing that we can also do to help these students fit back into Singapore society, and besides looking at relaxing the standards for the mother tongue grades, perhaps we could also look at accepting the grades that they have obtained overseas in their overseas educational systems. I think we are rather rigid in this and perhaps our universities, for example, could look into accepting the equivalent of `A' levels, so that these children will not be penalised.
