    Mr Iswaran: Sir, parenting is an under-rated skill that is taken for granted. The practitioners are generally left to their own devices. There are no courses, manuals or evaluations, except perhaps by their children. Parents usually rely on experiences within their family and circle of friends for references. Yet, as we have heard time and again today, parents play an important complementary role to our teachers in our schools.

    Sir, the members of the resource panel for the GPC for Education have highlighted the dissonance that exists between parents' perceptions of school life today, and the reality. Please allow me to illustrate.

    For most parents, their understanding and idea of life in school dates back to more than two decades ago. Back then, the advent of the hand-held calculator was momentous. Today, PCs are the norm.

    Parents are still grappling with the intricacies of our education system. In a sense, they themselves are streamed. Those in the fast track understand our system well.

Column: 1763

Others, whom I believe constitute the bulk, have a more approximate understanding.

    Parents are also unaware of some of the norms in our schools today. For example, what is the going rate for pocket money? In the business world, HR managers can consult salary reviews by consultants, like Hays, to get some reference points. Whom or what can parents turn to other than their intuition and perhaps casual discussions with their friends?

    Then there is the perennial question of what they call BGR - boy-girl relationships. What are the OB markers? What are the acceptable limits? Parents have to walk a tightrope for fear of being labelled as rude or a prude.

    These questions highlight the gaps, I think, in the awareness of today's parents. I believe that the Ministry of Education, perhaps in conjunction with MCD, could undertake some steps to better educate our parents as well. In particular, Sir, I urge the Ministry to consider the use of the Parent-Teacher Associations (PTAs), strengthening them and using them for this purpose. PTAs could facilitate regular discussions between the schools, the teachers, on the one hand, and the parents to help them to better understand and navigate our education system. At the same time, PTAs could facilitate group discussions amongst parents so that they may share their experiences.

    I would like to know whether the Ministry has any plans to further strengthen our PTA system and, in particular, in the area of parent education.

    Dr Lily Neo (Kreta Ayer-Tanglin): Sir, I doubt many will fault our education system in terms of first-rate facilities, in terms of fantastic academic results, and even in terms of free and fair opportunities for all our children. The Government and educators spare no effort in trying to let our young have the best. We should all be glad. But "no", we moan and we are disgruntled. We are not quite satisfied, and we tell the world and allow the world to tell us how stressed we are from the education of our children.

Column: 1764



    Sir, I contend that the problem has to do with our mindset on "success" and "competition for success". We are a success-orientated nation. It is only natural for parents to want success and the best for their children. Compete for it, if need be. It is not enough to assume that this is only part of kiasuism, and it is harmless. Having competition for betterment is not a bad thing at all. But when such competition becomes excessive and begins to look like a survival pre-requisite, we must take note. We need to change our mindset towards this type of "success" and this type of "competition for success". Although this may take years to achieve, we do have to start somewhere.

    Bearing in mind that the Government will help the children realise their maximal educational potential, let us see if life can be better when this is achieved, but with a different mindset. Consider emphasising a new ideology and interpreting an old policy somewhat differently from the way we do now. Let me use the following aspects of our present system to illustrate what I mean.

    (1) The introduction of a range of textbooks may be good for a whole lot of people, but it may not be so for the very people that matter, namely, the students. The idea of giving people a choice is right, but this offer, with the present mindset, opens the door to the problem of "too many books". It is not easy to have a "perfect" book, so parents will probably buy a couple more to be taught by tuition teachers. This cannot be good for the children. It is my opinion that, for the present, we should still have a standard textbook. From the books by various authors, the work that best represents the topic in the syllabus is extracted from such a textbook to be compiled. Some sort of a standard is thus made available to guide the students, teachers as well as parents. Sir, this way, the students will have less books to carry and the parents will have less books to buy. Indeed, the opposite will be awesome as there can be an endless amount of materials available out there in due course.

Column: 1765



    (2) It has been said that our students are doing too many subjects for the `O' levels. They say that "only 6 subjects count, but you can do as many subjects as you wish" and you have students doing 10 or more. This is just too much work, let alone too much stress. Let us try to reduce the number of subjects. What happens when the rule is "6 subjects count and you will be examined on only 7"? It is likely that students will not want to study more than 7 subjects for examination purposes. The Singaporean is pragmatic. Mind you, Sir, I am sure many students will still want to study more subjects, but they now can enjoy these other subjects for personal interest rather than for examinations. To deal with this more effectively, the authorities would need to modify and simplify the subject-combination choices.

    (3) Adding value to extra-curricular activities (ECAs) is a step in the right direction to encourage students to be all-rounders. However, the mindset is that there is a "new subject" to score from. All at once, ECAs will be in addition to the academic workload. If the rule for admission to course X is "get 3As+1B and your ECAs can give you further advantage", stress is increased, because the requirement for course X now becomes 3As+1B+ECAs and the "new subject" must be pursued. Let us please emphasise that to do course X, just get 3As+1B, and if you should get only 2As+2Bs, your ECAs can help make up the deficit.

    (4) Standards and requirements should not fluctuate too much year to year. If a student with 3As+1B in subjects PQRS is eligible for course X in one year, then another student with the same results in another year should also qualify. In other words, an inclusive, rather than exclusive, policy should be adopted. You want course X? Just get 3As+1B, and that is all. You have what you want. Let the standards be more finite.

    Sir, I fear that our education system may become too exclusive if we do not simplify more and quantify less. This mindset of our people should be borne in mind when we change policy or introduce new ideas.

Column: 1766


5.00 pm

    Dr Tan Boon Wan: Sir, our young are unflatteringly described as smart, but self-centred, selfish, and lacking in humility, moral values and community spirit. Let me illustrate this with two frequent complaints.

    Students litter and vandalise common facilities without thought. They do not care about the community who lives there and uses the facilities. Employers have complained of being interviewed by young graduates instead of the other way round. The graduates were more concerned with their own interests rather than the needs of the company and the job. It is the extremity of the position that the graduates take that is a worrying sign.

    Sir, our young are our future. Today we are still able to influence the course of the nation, but tomorrow we have to depend on them to do it. The attitude and mindset of our young to duties to the nation, society and community, is of great concern. Without a strong sense of community responsibilities and duties among our young, the future of the nation stands on flimsy ground. This is a pressing and serious issue. Deputy Prime Minister, BG Lee Hsien Loong, has spoken eloquently and persuasively on this issue in his recent ministerial statement on bond breaking.

    Sir, lest I am accused of being unfair to our youths, let me hasten to add that the sense of community responsibilities and duties of our youth is high. But we are noticing a downward trend. We cannot shrug off this concern by reassuring ourselves that somehow things will turn out right as in the past. The whole society, including the school, community and parents, has duties and responsibilities for the moral development of our young and I would urge each to make conscious efforts to do more.

    Our children do spend a substantial amount of their waking hours in the schools, in the company of their teachers and school friends. I am happy to note that the Ministry has recognised the importance of the role of the school and developed several programmes to foster

Column: 1767

community spirit and to widen the outlook of our students beyond mere school books and examinations. National education is one example. The requirement that each of our secondary school and junior college students performs 6 hours of community service is another. The recent Learning Journey programme adds to the opportunities available to our students to learn more about country and community.

    I applaud our companies who have opened their doors to our students. Participation will cost them time, money and manpower resources. Hence it is a noble act on their part to serve the wider interest of the community. I hope more organisations in both the public and private sectors will take part. However, the key must be the principals and teachers. They must be convinced that these are desirable programmes and will support them fully.

    The community, too, has its role in the moral development of our young. The young learned from what they see going on around them. If adults behave responsibly and show care for the community, such as protecting and properly using common properties, in showing care and respect for one another, our young will emulate these behaviours. In the debate on last year's Budget, I called upon grassroots organisations to work with the schools to give our students the opportunity to do community work. The recently announced Community Involvement Scheme for our secondary school and junior college students will make this task easier. Grassroots organisations like the CCCs, CCMCs, RCs, Town Councils and CDCs should seize the opportunity to work with the schools to provide more opportunities for students to serve the community. Besides making our young better and caring people, some of them may well stay on to become the next generation of grassroots leaders. The lament that not enough residents are coming forward to serve may, in a few short years' time, be a thing of the past.

    Sir, the ultimate responsibility for the moral development of a child rests with the parents. Parents must accept this responsibility. Some have tended to put

Column: 1768

the blame on society and the schools for their children going wayward. Parents must find time to spend with their children, and during these times to discuss and impart family and social values. They must realise that the children grow up to be like them as the children emulate not just what they advocate, but more, what they do. Parenting is a heavy task and responsibility. Unfortunately, society does not impose any qualifications to become a parent. We learn from experience and our mistakes, but by which time our children would have grown up. I believe that courses in parenting are necessary and important and will help many to be better parents. I would like grassroots organisations to take up the challenge to conduct parenting seminars and courses for young parents in the community. Some community organisations like AMP, Mendaki and Family Service Centres are already doing this. These efforts will help our schools and teachers in doing their work.

    The Minister for Education (RAdm Teo Chee Hean): First of all, I would like to thank Members, especially Mr Loh Meng See and his GPC members, for their feedback, comments and suggestions so far. I am grateful that so many Members have taken such an active interest in education. It is always refreshing to have ideas coming from different perspectives, challenging our assumptions and triggering off even more ideas on how we can do better.

    We have a good education system which has been developed over the years through strong leadership, clear foresight and determination, and through the commitment and hard work of teachers, students and parents. We have achieved good results by international standards. Nevertheless, we are often our own harshest critics; and that should be the way. We should never be satisfied with what we have. We need to continue improving our education system, building upon the solid foundation that we have. We must maintain the rigour and high standards of our system as we make adjustments and improvements. This principle undergirds all our efforts.

Column: 1769



    Providing a good education is our investment in Singapore's future. The currency crisis and its ripple effects underscore the importance of sound fundamentals.

    Sound fundamentals extend beyond prudent economic and financial management to include preparing the next generation to face any combination of possible future scenarios. In times of prosperity, it is the people of Singapore who must seize the opportunities and even create new opportunities. In times of adversity, it is the people of Singapore who must turn adversity into opportunity.

    In our schools, our young must learn not just the knowledge and skills for the economy of the future, but also values and instincts so that when they come of age, they, collectively, will be able to face the future with confidence and steadfastness, identify the real problems, find the best solutions and chart Singapore's destiny. The better we develop their talents and abilities, the better will be the home that we build together for the future.

    Our young people are the future of Singapore. And the Government has shown its commitment to invest in our future through good times and through not so good times. This year, although the Minister for Finance has allocated a significantly larger budget for education, we should not imagine that funds are unlimited. The Minister for Finance still keeps a tight rein on things. Nor should we go away with the idea that more spending is the solution for all our problems.

    Spending more money does not ensure that we will have a better system. I agree with those Members who have expressed the view that it is the "software" in our system that counts. What we spend on, and how we spend, is more important. In June last year, Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong unveiled the vision of Thinking Schools, Learning Nation to prepare our young for the future. Allow me to provide an update on what the Ministry of Education has done to move towards this vision.

Column: 1770



    The first step is to define our goals. In any long journey, we need to set out with a purpose in mind. We need to ask ourselves what is it that we want formal education to achieve. Given our transition to a knowledge-based economy, given the demands of life in the 21st century, given a likely picture of the social environment in the future, what attributes do we want Singaporeans to have? What characteristics should our community, business, professional and national leaders possess? What intermediate outcomes should primary, secondary and junior college education achieve?

    In January this year, the Ministry of Education published a document called "The Desired Outcomes of Education" and Members have a copy of it before them. I need not read it out to you. Some Members have already done this favour on my behalf. This document defines the aims of a holistic education by giving a comprehensive yet succinct list of values, skills and attitudes our young at different stages of their education should possess. The press has dubbed this the "88888" list, which I think is quite appropriate.

    "The Desired Outcomes of Education" is a reaffirmation of what educationists, parents, teachers and students have all along wanted a good education to provide. The list was drawn up after extensive consultation with our principals and teachers.

    You will notice that explicit academic achievement targets are conspicuously absent from the list. This is not an oversight. Cognitive development is one of the desired outcomes. And academic performance is one of the ways, and a well-accepted, objective and rigorous one, by which we can measure cognitive development. It is a good indicator, but by no means a comprehensive one nor the only one. But we can all agree that we are looking for more than that from education. Our intention is to deliver holistic education in partnership with parents and the community.

    Some wonder if the pursuit of holistic education will mean a drop in academic standards. I do not think so. I cannot see

Column: 1771

why a more morally upright, socially responsible student should perform less well academically. I cannot see how a more independent, creative thinker can do worse than someone who relies on reproducing facts and content. This is not a matter of sacrificing academic standards to nurture students with high moral standards and community spirit. This is not an "either-or" situation. Holistic education is entirely possible with high academic achievement. Getting good grades in examinations should be a product of holistic education, but I agree with Mr Peh Chin Hua that it should not be an all-consuming passion in itself, pursued to the exclusion of everything else.

    An organisation sets itself performance targets for two purposes: to focus the efforts of the organisation, and to measure the progress they are making towards achieving their targets. Focusing efforts is important to the Ministry of Education because in the provision of education, as we can hear today, there are many `good' things we can do. We want to make sure we direct our efforts at those activities that go furthest in achieving our aims. But the issue of measuring our achievements does pose some problems. How will the Ministry of Education know if we have achieved these desired outcomes? What are our yardsticks?

    The measure of success will not be easily quantifiable. How, for example, do we quantify compassion for others? How can we objectively measure a student's love for his country or his commitment to the nation? Perhaps we will know, not when we have succeeded, but when we have failed. However, the fact that we have no reliable measure does not mean that we should give up delivering holistic education. Ten or twenty years down the road, if we succeed, our economy will be more prosperous, our nation will be more united, our society more gracious, our people more creative, our community more cohesive. These outcomes may not be easily quantifiable nor tangible, but they are no less real, and are absolutely critical for our future.

    May I now update the House on the progress of various specific initiatives my

Column: 1772

Ministry has undertaken in the past year to achieve the goal of Thinking Schools, Learning Nation, and The Desired Outcomes of Education.

    First, National Education. Members will remember that the objective of National Education is to foster a Singapore identity, and to help our young understand the challenges and constraints confronting Singapore. Efforts are ongoing to infuse National Education into different subject syllabuses. You will have learnt through the media about the imaginative and engaging ways our schools are bringing the National Education messages across, even in extra-curricular activities.
5.15 pm

    In October last year, we also launched the Community Involvement Programme. Through this Programme, we hope that our young will learn to be active participants in community and national life when they grow up.

    Our schools have also started to commemorate key historical events in Singapore's history. Besides National Day, schools now commemorate three other events. These are Total Defence Day, Racial Harmony Day and International Friendship Day.

    At the end of last month, `Learning Journeys' were launched. Pupils from Primary Four to JC2 will visit key national institutions at least once a year. We hope that our students can understand the country's constraints and vulnerabilities, develop a sense of pride in Singapore, and a confidence that with ingenuity, determination and hard work, Singapore will remain an exceptional island-nation for a long time to come.

    Next, the Masterplan for Information Technology in Education. Phase 1 of the IT Masterplan has been successfully implemented in 22 demonstration schools, comprising 10 primary schools, 10 secondary schools and 2 junior colleges. On 4th April, these schools will be holding an open house, and I invite Members to drop by and have a look. We are now embarking on Phase 2 involving 100 schools. In 1999, we will move on to the remaining 240 schools.

Column: 1773



    However, buying and installing hardware is relatively simple compared to the training of our teachers and providing our teachers with the necessary guidance and support. This is most critical to the success of the Masterplan. And it is here that the Ministry of Education has focused its main effort.

    All trainee teachers in NIE now undergo a course in IT. Basic IT literacy training for all serving teachers has also been completed. As their schools come on stream under the IT Masterplan, teachers will receive further preparation and training which will include the design of lesson plans and the use of different kinds of software. IT instructors from the Ministry of Education go to the schools to work with the teachers and sometimes even co-teach in classrooms so that our teachers are able to learn by observation and practice.

    We have also set up a Media Services Section which reviews and recommends software titles and websites. These are classified by subjects and by levels. Teachers have access to this via the Ministry of Education Intranet. There are currently about 350 software titles posted on this site. I hope this goes some way to address the concerns raised by Dr Tan Boon Wan.

    The introduction of new technology at such a pace into the schools is a little daunting. But this is the pace at which the IT industry is moving. Our schools, which must prepare our students for the world of tomorrow, cannot be behind what is already commonplace in the workplace. We need to put computers into the hands of our teachers. After an initial one or two years of learning, experimentation and experience, I am confident that our teachers will be able to use computers as a powerful tool to enhance the learning and teaching that goes on in our schools.

    We also pressed on with initiatives in school administration. The School Cluster scheme was piloted last year to devolve greater autonomy to schools in order to enhance school management. In

Column: 1774

November 1997, the Ministry introduced five more clusters: 2 primary and 2 secondary clusters, with one mixed primary-secondary cluster. A junior college was also added to one of the original clusters formed in early 1997. The reason for mixing different schools in the same cluster is to add variety and richness of experience to the cluster.

    The final and fourth initiative, perhaps the most important one announced last year, is fostering creative thinking and reviewing the curriculum. The curriculum is important, as it is the medium through which most initiatives in teaching and learning take place.

    There is no shortage of ideas as to what we should add to the curriculum - everyone has his or her pet topics to put in: modern art, Singapore literature, astronomy, even swimming and life-saving skills. There are comments that our students today are not as knowledgeable or as well prepared as their predecessors, ergo, they should be better prepared. Several have commented that our curriculum is too narrow and should be broadened.

    However, many have also expressed the view that our national curriculum is too content-heavy, and does not lend itself to the development of creativity and critical thinking skills. But we must not forget that each topic already there in the curriculum was put there for a good reason - to achieve a specific learning outcome. The problem then is not a shortage of good ideas as to what to put into the curriculum. The real question is the opposite one: among all these wonderful ideas, what should we leave out? That is the real challenge. After all, there is only so much time in a day and so much that we can ask our children to cope with.

    When we look at the various curricula in different education systems, and I visited a number of countries this past year, it does not mean that one with more subjects, more topics, more content is better. For example, if someone tells me, "Look, the curriculum of this school system covers all that is taught in our school system in Singapore and much

Column: 1775

more. It must be better, let's follow it." I would say, "Stop, think a while, think very carefully.". Most parents would agree that what their children are now doing in school is already quite a heavy load, and we should beware the "more is better" syndrome. In our case, teaching less may allow us to teach better. If anyone has found a magic formula to teach our national curriculum and more without over-stressing our kids, please let me know. I would like to find out how it is done.

    The British have decided that they are trying to do too much in their primary schools and are failing to provide sufficient focus on the basics. In January this year, the British Education and Employment Secretary Mr David Blunkett announced that from this year, British primary schools will focus on just four things: English, Mathematics, Science and Information Technology. Minimum teaching hours are mandated for these four subjects. The prescribed programme for the six other subjects in the curriculum have been suspended, and primary schools are no longer required to follow them.

    However, the solution obviously is not simply to slash our syllabuses. We have to balance breadth and depth. We want to maintain the rigour in our curriculum and the high standards in our schools. We need to develop and to deliver an essential core of knowledge in each subject, and to overlay this with higher order thinking skills. Creative and critical thinking cannot occur in a vacuum, they can only be learnt and applied in the context of some content knowledge. We also want to design a curriculum that adequately stretches our most able students. At the same time, we must be mindful of our less able students. We must not leave them way behind, unable to catch up, discouraged and disillusioned with school.

    In October 1996, the Ministry of Education invited a senior academic, Prof. Hang Chang Chieh, Deputy Vice-Chancellor of the National University of Singapore, to lead an external review of our curriculum and assessment system.

Column: 1776

The objective was to provide a fresh perspective; a perspective of recipients of the products of our school system - universities, polytechnics, and future employers of our students - as to what they would like to see being taught in our schools. The committee submitted its report to the Ministry of Education in August 1997.

    The Report has been studied by the Ministry of Education. One of the main themes in the report is that the syllabuses are generally too heavy and should be cut back to allow more time for creative thinking and application of knowledge through activities such as project work in the schools.

    The Ministry has decided to implement the recommendations which the committee has made on the curriculum in a major review which we are now undertaking. But this review will take several years as it is a major review that will involve not only what we teach, but how we teach it and how it is assessed. In this review, we want to make sure that not only do our students acquire content and factual knowledge, but also process skills. These are significant changes, and we will need some time to study them carefully, consult experts and users, orient teachers, make course materials and design assessment systems. We can only introduce the bulk of these changes into the schools from the year 2001 onwards.

    In the meantime, we have decided to take some interim measures to reduce the curriculum load on our students. With very few exceptions, most syllabuses will be reduced by 10% to 30%, most of them in the range of 10% to 20%. However, there will be no change to the structure of the syllabuses, nor to the examinations nor the type of questions that will be set. These interim curriculum reductions can therefore be introduced into the schools from next year. Some schools may already have selectively omitted teaching certain topics; these curricular cuts make it official.

    Content which has been reduced or cut include those which focus mainly on recall, or technical details not critical to

Column: 1777

students' understanding of the topic. Content inconsistent with real world practice, too difficult or too broad has also been cut. Content which is repeated either at other levels or in a different subject may be retained in one subject at a particular level, and removed from the others.

    This will lighten the load so that teachers and students can have more time to implement the initiatives that we introduced in the last year. This will free up time for more collaborative learning, more self-directed research, more independent investigations, to develop process skills, thinking skills, and communication skills.

    These reduced syllabuses will take effect next year, and students will be examined on these reduced syllabuses from the year 2000 onwards. This is the first step we are taking, so that there can be an immediate reduction in curriculum load. Teachers and students should have no difficulty adapting to this reduction, as it only involves removing some topics, while the remaining topics and the examination system remain the same.

    This immediate reduction will allow a lightening of the load from next year, while we do a more thorough review of the curriculum and our assessment system to see how we can better bring out the creative spirit and thinking ability of our young. Changes to the curriculum, if not accompanied by corresponding changes to assessment modes, teaching methodologies, learning resources and learner attitudes, are likely to be futile. The Ministry of Education will continue to work on these other areas. As I said earlier, we will not be able to introduce these major changes earlier than 2001 into the schools.

    All the progress described above would not have been possible, or will come to naught, without the teacher. Teachers are key to everything that we do in the education system. As I said last year, teachers are the heart and the soul of our system. They are out there in the classrooms, in the science laboratories, in the school field, delivering total education.

Column: 1778

The best physical facilities and most innovative curriculum will not come to life without dedicated and competent teachers.
5.30 pm

    I fully endorse the support that Mr Loh Meng See, Mr Peh Chin Hua, Mr Lim Swee Say and others have given to our teachers. We will take their comments and suggestions on how we can improve the teaching service into account. The teacher plays a crucial role in nation-building. The teacher's role goes beyond ensuring the employability of the next generation. It covers the development of his charges in all areas described in the Desired Outcomes.

    Teachers shape the values of their students, and instil in them a strong sense of social conscience. Teachers are role models of lifelong learning to their students. Teaching is not an easy job, but it is highly rewarding. It requires people who are caring and nurturing, those who have a sense of mission and calling. There is an immense satisfaction in moulding young minds, shaping lives, helping and encouraging people who will go on to help and encourage others. It almost certainly involves tears and heartaches, but ask any teacher, and he or she will tell you that it is a job that it is totally rewarding.

    Despite the many demands placed on them, the vast majority of teachers like what they are doing. The Ministry of Education recently conducted a Teachers' Survey and I would like to share some of the preliminary findings with this House. As I expected, the vast majority, 83%, of teachers indicated that they like the type of work that they do. Teaching is intrisincally satisfying. This is befitting of a people-centred, people-development profession. 83% indicated that their job makes good use of their abilities, and 88% feel that they can count on support and assistance from their colleagues when faced with a difficulty.

    As some Members in the House, Dr Tan Boon Wan, Dr Toh See Kiat, Mr Iswaran, Mr Lim Swee Say and others have said, they have heard of teachers feeling

Column: 1779

stressed by the rapid pace of change and the amount of work in the schools. In this past year, I visited many schools and I have talked to many teachers. Yes, there is stress and there is worry. Our teachers work very hard. Our teachers have a tremendous sense of responsibility towards the young under their charge and want to do the best for them.

    I am encouraged by the response of our teachers. They are convinced that the changes that we are making to the education system are important and necessary. But change is unsettling. Even as our teachers do their best to deliver high quality education today, they worry about how they will continue to do their best with infusing National Education, or learning to use IT, or dealing with more demanding parents.

    Perhaps because we have consciously announced initiatives to all teachers way before implementing them in schools, some of our teachers suffer from the stress of anticipating stress! I would like to assure the House that it is not the Ministry of Education's intention to simply think up these initiatives and load them on to the schools. We will guide our schools and teachers each step of the way. As I said earlier, when introducing IT in the demonstration schools, we sent experts from the Ministry to work together with and guide our teachers. And as more schools and teachers get into the IT habit, the scope for shared learning and faster learning will be enlarged. In National Education, we also have guided our principals and National Education coordinators through various teething problems of implementation.

    The early and timely announcement of our various initiatives gives principals and teachers time to adapt and adjust. For example, the IT Masterplan will reach the majority of our schools (two-thirds of them, or 240 of our 360 schools) only next year, two years after we launched the IT Masterplan. These principals and teachers have two years to prepare themselves for this change. Those schools and principals and teachers who felt more ready have been those who have come in in Phase I and Phase II.

Column: 1780



    The Ministry of Education is committed to providing teachers with the support for personal and professional development so that they can in turn do their jobs well. It is useful for me to highlight some of the key improvements we have made to help teachers to do their jobs better.

    In recent years, the Ministry of Education has implemented a series of measures to alleviate teachers' workload. These include the posting of school administrators and operations managers to perform certain administrative and support functions, the streamlining of work procedures (mundane things like payment of school fees is now done by GIRO, centrally issuing student travel passes so that teachers do not have to keep on sticking these things on), and leveraging on IT to improve work efficiency (like pre-printed class registers).

    Sir, what can be made of any student in our education system depends primarily on the interplay of three factors: character development, motivation and ability. Character development is most important because the student must decide how he wants to use his knowledge and abilities - to serve only himself or to serve others, to do right under all circumstances or only if he stands a high chance of being caught. But character formation takes place almost from the time of birth, so that children in Primary 1 comes to school already with values ingrained in them in their homes, by their parents. Our schools conduct moral education and civics, but these lessons cannot exist in a vacuum. They will either be reinforced or thwarted by messages from home.

The school encourages children to learn, mostly by coaching, reward and building self-esteem, but sometimes by punishment and discipline. At times, our principals and teachers may be pushing too hard. They want to do their best for their students. And parents expect them to.     Motivation is strongly influenced by what happens at home. Which parent does not believe that his child can do better?
